It is said that based on meditative concentration, in the perfection of abiding in guarding against the arising of afflictions in others, it is samÄdhi, prajÃ±Ä, and the various mental factors associated with them.
Why is it so?

If one who abides in the absence of conflict wishes to go to all places where sentient beings should be seen, first, in the place where one resides, one uses the power of aspiration and wisdom to contemplate whether afflictions will arise in the future for those sentient beings towards one's body.
Having contemplated in this way, if one knows that afflictions such as desire, anger, stinginess, and jealousy will arise towards oneself, one will not go. If they will not arise, one will go there.
Because one is able to guard against the afflictions and conflicts of others and prevent them from arising, it is called the absence of conflict.
The knowledge of vows is the concentration and wisdom in the perfection of vows for realizing what is to be known, based on the formless concentrations. The rest is as before.
Why is it so?

Because one who has attained the knowledge of vows, in order to realize all the things to be known in the three times, first arouses the mind of right vows regarding those things, vowing to truly realize such and such. Next, he enters the supreme concentration.
After arising from that, his vows are fulfilled, because he is able to realize what is to be known.

The unobstructed understanding of dharmas, the unobstructed understanding of meanings, the unobstructed understanding of expressions, and the unobstructed understanding of eloquence.

As for the supernormal powers, there are six kinds of supernormal powers:

1. The supernormal power of spiritual penetrations, 2. The supernormal power of the divine ear, 3. The supernormal power of discerning the minds of others, 4. The supernormal power of recollecting past lives, 5. The supernormal power of knowing the end of the cycle of birth and death, 6. The supernormal power of the extinction of contaminations.

Various sounds refer to the sounds of humans, gods, etc.

The supernormal power of discerning the minds of others means, based on the dhyanas, the samadhi and wisdom regarding the mastery of penetrating the differences in the mental activities of other sentient beings, as explained before.

As for observing the differences in the deaths and rebirths of sentient beings, it means using the heavenly eye to observe the deaths and rebirths of sentient beings, their good and bad appearances, and their future destinies, whether going to good or evil realms.

As for the major and minor marks, it means that based on the dhyanas, in the power of manifesting the adornment of the support of the major and minor marks, it is samadhi and prajna, as well as the associated mind and mental factors, and the resultant ripening that arises from them.

The four fearlessnesses are:

The fearlessness of perfect enlightenment refers to the concentration and wisdom, and the mental factors associated with them, that are based on the dhyanas, through the door of benefiting oneself, in the complete fulfillment of the proclamation of one's own virtues as a perfectly enlightened one with regard to all kinds of knowable objects.
As a sutra says:

I am a perfectly enlightened one. If there are any in the world, whether shramanas, Brahmins, gods, maras, or Brahmas, who on the basis of the Dharma raise objections or cause me to remember, saying that with regard to this Dharma I am not perfectly enlightened,
I see no grounds for this.

Because I see no grounds for this, I dwell in peace, free from fear and anxiety. I proclaim myself to be the great sage, the honored one, and in the great assembly I roar the lion's roar and turn the great Brahma wheel. No shramana, Brahmin, god, mara, or Brahma in the world can turn it.

The eighteen distinctive qualities of the Buddha are the eighteen distinctive qualities of the Buddha.

What are the eighteen?
As the sutra says:

The Tathagata has no errors, no abrupt speech, no forgetfulness, no distracted mind, no various thoughts, no indiscriminate abandonment, his will does not regress, his effort does not regress, his mindfulness does not regress, his concentration does not regress, his wisdom does not regress, his liberation does not regress, all his physical actions are guided by wisdom and turn according to wisdom, all his verbal actions are guided by wisdom and turn according to wisdom, all his mental actions are guided by wisdom and turn according to wisdom, he knows the past without attachment or obstruction, he knows the future without attachment or obstruction, he knows the present without attachment or obstruction.

The knowledge of all modes is the concentration and wisdom, and the mind and mental activities associated with them, in the nature of the complete knowledge of all modes of the aggregates, elements, and sense bases.
What is meant by the complete knowledge of all modes of the aggregates, elements, and sense bases?
It means the realization of all distinctions in the characteristics of the self-natures and distinctions of the aggregates, etc., and the fulfillment of the knowledge of the ultimate limit.
How does one give rise to such merits?
It means relying on the four pure meditations.

Whether it is non-Buddhists, Å›rÄvakas, or bodhisattvas, they give rise to the four immeasurables and five supernormal knowledges, mostly relying on the ultimate fourth meditation. Whether it is Å›rÄvakas, bodhisattvas, or tathÄgatas, they give rise to the remaining merits.
What is the cause for giving rise to such merits?
It means relying on meditation and repeatedly contemplating the dharmas as established.
Herein, it shows the basis for the manifestation of such virtues, the individual who can manifest them, and the means by which they are manifested.
How are they manifested?
It means that with a concentrated mind, one repeatedly contemplates the characteristics of the teachings that have been established.

When wishing to manifest the immeasurables, one relies on meditative absorption, and repeatedly contemplates with a mind accompanied by loving-kindness, free from resentment and enmity, and so forth, using the wisdom of cultivation and attention.

When wishing to manifest spiritual powers and so forth, one relies on meditative absorption, and repeatedly contemplates transforming one into many and so forth, using the wisdom of cultivation and attention.
In this way, one repeatedly contemplates in all cases, as is appropriate, according to the established teachings.
Moreover, such virtues are generally of two kinds:
One is the manifestation of one's own function, and the other is the abiding in one's own nature.
If it is the case of manifesting and initiating one's own function, it takes the supramundane subsequently attained conventional wisdom as its essence.
If it is the case of abiding in its own nature, it takes the supramundane wisdom as its essence.

Moreover, as for manifesting and initiating one's own function, it refers to the sages according to their respective capacities manifesting and initiating various activities such as eliminating the obstacles to be eliminated, and so forth.
As for abiding in its own nature, it refers to the supreme tranquil non-discriminating wisdom embracing the immeasurable and so forth of abiding in the present enjoyment of the Dharma.
Next, what function do the immeasurables perform?

It is said: Because of abandoning the obstacles to be eliminated, and because of abiding in compassion, one is able to quickly perfect the accumulation of merit and virtue, and to mature sentient beings without becoming weary.
As for abandoning the obstacles to be eliminated, it refers to the four immeasurables being able to abandon hatred, harm, unhappiness, and love and anger respectively.
As for abiding in compassion, it refers to the four immeasurables turning and abiding in accordance with the matter of benefiting sentient beings.
Because of abiding in compassion for all sentient beings, one is able to quickly perfect the requisites of merit.
The mind is tireless in maturing sentient beings because of compassion for sentient beings and disregard for one's own body.
What function does liberation perform?
It causes the manifestation of transformations, and in pure and impure transformations there is no difficulty.
In tranquil liberation there is no obstruction, and one is able to abide in the foremost tranquil holy abode, by means of superior resolve and contemplation.
Herein, it is shown that the first two liberations are able to cause the manifestation of transformations.
By means of the third liberation, in pure and impure transformations there is no difficulty.
By means of the four formless liberations, in tranquil liberation there is no obstruction.
By means of the final liberation, one is able to abide in the foremost tranquil holy abode.
By means of superior resolve and contemplation shows that the meaning of such and such superior resolve is the meaning of liberation.
What function does mastery perform?
That is, they enable the objects of the first three deliverances to be freely transformed, because they subdue the objects.
What is the action of the bases of spiritual power?
That is, they are able to accomplish the objects of the deliverances and pervade and spread them.
What is the action of the absence of conflict?

That is, when one utters speech, all who hear it are subdued and believe it, because it most effectively protects the minds of others and because it utters speech in accordance with what is appropriate.
What is the action of the knowledge of resolve?
That is, it is able to discern well the events of the three times, etc., and all worlds revere it, because it penetrates all and is the object of universal respect.
What is the action of the unhindered discernments?
That is, it skillfully preaches the essentials of the Dharma and delights the minds of multitudes, because it is able to sever all doubts and nets .
What is the action of the supernormal powers?
That is, it uses the actions of body and speech and the communication of thought to transform and guide sentient beings and cause them to enter the holy teachings.
It well knows all the mental activities of sentient beings and their past and future, and it instructs them as is appropriate so that they may eternally escape .

Here it shows the supernormal powers of spiritual penetrations, such as the divine eye and the elimination of contaminants, which are able to give rise to bodily actions such as spiritual transformations and guidance, because the divine ear supernormal power understands all distinctions in sounds and can lead to verbal actions.
What function do the major and minor marks perform?
It is said that they cause one to be regarded as a great being upon a brief encounter, and give rise to pure faith in the mind.
What function does purity perform?

It is said that by this power one takes rebirth according to one's wishes, either abiding for one eon, or for the remainder of an eon, or abandoning the practice of longevity, or freely transforming the body, or freely transforming the various concentrations, or upholding the true Dharma of the buddhas.
Here it shows that by the purity of the support, one has mastery over taking, abiding, and abandoning the supported body according to one's wishes.
